column1: The Batavia Society of Art and Science also specialized in social sciences. In 1817 it made the plans for the Hortus Botanicus Bogoriense in Bogor. column1: During the brief period of Japanese occupation between 1942 and 1945
column2: there was a stimulation on Indonesian culture. One of the cultural society established by the colonial Japanese government was the Keimin Bunka Sidosho or KBS in 1943. The core policy of the KBS is to promote the cultural unity of the "Greater East Asia". Agus Jaya was appointed as head of the arts
column3: Usmar Ismail as head of film and drama
column4: Armijn Pane as head of literature
column5: and Ibu Sud as head of dance and singing. The KBS actively held exhibitions and performances in big cities of the Japanese-occupied Dutch East Indies. During the three-and-a-half years of Japanese occupation
column6: the Indonesian arts flourish with dozens of art exhibitions
column8: and awards. Among local artists member of the KBS were Emiria Sunassa

column1: The newly independent government of Indonesia established the Ministry of Education and Culture in accordance with Article 32 in the 1945 Constitution. The Department of Culture was divided into Archaeological
column3: and Language Divisions. The Art Division set up several educational institutions including the Indonesian Academy of Fine Arts in Yogyakarta (1950)
column4: the Indonesian School of Music in Yogyakarta (1952)
column5: and Karawitan Conservatoire in Surakarta (1950). In 1952
column6: The Language Division was split into two
column7: the first one retained the same name and the same position in the Department of Culture
column8: the other was included in the Institute of Literature (former Instituut voor Taal en Cultuur Onderzoek
column9: Faculteit der Lettera en Wijsbegeerte van de Universiteit van Indonesia). Also in 1952
column10: the Department of Culture opened provincial "cultural offices" in Medan (North Sumatra)
column18: there were several changes in the Department of Culture
column19: which include the additional responsibility of museum management (the Museum Section). Other changes were: the conversion of the Archaeological Division into the autonomous Institute of Archaeology; the Language Division in the Institute of Literature became the Language Division of the Literary Faculty of Indonesia; and the Language Division became the Sub-Division of Customs and Traditions.Later
column20: the Department of Culture was included into the Directorate of Culture as part of the ministerial reorganization of the 1960s. The reorganization also converted the Museum Section into the autonomous National Museum Institute. Following the reorganization
column21: the Ministry of Education and Culture consisted of one Directorate of Culture and four autonomous institutes: Archaeology
column24: and History & Anthropology. The responsibility of opening provincial "cultural offices" was given to the Inspectorate of Provincial Culture.

column2: the regime of Suharto converted the Ministry of Education and Culture into five Directorates-General. The Directorate-General of Culture itself was divided into five directorates: Art
column6: and Language & Literature. Other restructuring occurred in 1969
column7: reducing the Directorates-General into three; this time the Directorate-General of Culture consisted of three directorates: Art

column12: and Music & Choreography.The New Order period also saw the expansion of the Armed Forces History Center and the encouragement of the development of museums of militaristic in nature. One of the reason for military involvement at first is because of the problem of internal divisions. This led to an accepted strategy of promoting shared values and identity across the forces through the use of a centralized military museum for older and younger generations of the soldiers. Some of these museums for which the Armed Forces was directly responsible are Satria Mandala Armed Forces Museum (opened in 1972)

column1: The number of museums in Indonesia in 1945 was 26 (including aquariums
column3: and botanical gardens (following the definition of the International Council of Museums). Between 1945 and 1968
column4: this increased to 46. In 2010 there were 281 museums in Indonesia
column5: 80 of which are State Museums. At the beginning of 2015
column6: the number of museums in Indonesia was 325. As of May 2015
column7: Indonesia had 412 museums.The Directorate for Museums introduced categories for the various collection types: there are general and special museums
column8: there are privately maintained and state-run museums
column9: both by the central and provincial governments. Those museums kept by the central government in the main operate under the administration of the Ministry of Education and Culture. Military museums are supervised by the Defence Ministry.The most frequent type is the General Provincial Museum (Museum Umum Propinsi) which exists in almost all provincial capitals. These museums usually consist of several sections: natural history (geological
column12: and history. Objects are sometimes flatly arranged in display cases with poor explanations. More recently established museums have already achieved higher standards with thoughtful and appealing expositions.In Indonesia
column13: the increase in the number of museums has not yet been matched by an increase in quality. Buildings are often unsuitable for display and for socio-educational activities; competent staffs are lacking; the public does not yet appreciate the educational role of museums; funds are lacking to maintain collections and extend building; and so on. There are not enough museums for 120 million inhabitants and a large number of State and private universities. Big cities like Jakarta
column16: Bandung and Semarang need centers for science and culture
column17: and museums as places of study and leisure.

column1: Jakarta contains the most museums in Indonesia with over 50 museums within its 661 square kilometers area. The museums in Jakarta cluster around the Central Jakarta Merdeka Square area
The Jakarta Old Town contains museums that are former institutional buildings of Colonial Batavia. Some of the notable museums are: Jakarta History Museum (former City Hall of Batavia)
column3: the Fine Art and Ceramic Museum (former Court House of Justice of Batavia)
column4: the Maritime Museum (former Sunda Kelapa warehouse)
column6: and Bank Mandiri Museum (former Netherlands Trading Society).
